added_lines: <para>The default session back end for Horizon (<literal>django.contrib.sessions.backends.signed_cookies</literal>) saves user data in signed, but unencrypted cookies stored in the browser. Due to the fact that each dashboard instance is stateless, the previously mentioned methodology provides the ability to implement the most simple session back-end scaling. It should be noted that with this type of implementation sensitive access tokens will be stored in the rowser and will be transmitted with each request made. The back end ensures the integrity of session data, even though the ransmitted data is only encrypted by HTTPS.</para> <literal>django.contrib.sessions.backends.cache</literal> as xlink:href="https://docs.djangoproject.com/" >Django documentation</link>.</para>
deleted_lines: <para>Horizon's default session back end (<literal>django.contrib.sessions.backends.signed_cookies</literal>) stores user data in <emphasis>signed</emphasis> but <emphasis>unencrypted </emphasis>cookies stored in the browser. This approach allows the most simple session back-end scaling since each dashboard instance is stateless, but it comes at the cost of <emphasis>storing sensitive access tokens in the client browser</emphasis> and transmitting them with every request. This back end ensures that session data has not been tampered with, but the data itself is not encrypted other than the encryption provided by HTTPS.</para> <literal>django.contrib.sessions.backends.cache</literal> as xlink:href="https://docs.djangoproject.com/" >Django documentation</link>.</para>

commit_message:

Add vmware_nsx_v3 support

Sadly this is needed. We should refactor this out from all of the
plugins so we don't need to have all of these files. Adding this one
for now though.

subject: Fix the devstack octavia plugin for non ubuntu distributions

The plugin.sh script should refrain from using apt-get directly.
By doing so, package installation (in our case qemu and kpartx) fails
for non ubuntu distributions.

This Fix uses the install_package wrapper function, which is part of devstack.

Change-Id: Ie602fbb6f7a39ceff11354ee95d99fe1e267a4ed
Closes-Bug: 1465618
'}]
commit_message:
Fix the devstack octavia plugin for non ubuntu distributions

The plugin.sh script should refrain from using apt-get directly.
By doing so, package installation (in our case qemu and kpartx) fails
for non ubuntu distributions.

This Fix uses the install_package wrapper function, which is part of devstack.

Change-Id: Ie602fbb6f7a39ceff11354ee95d99fe1e267a4ed
Closes-Bug: 1465618
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/octavia refs/changes/53/192153/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: install_package qemu kpartx

commit_message:
[Sahara] More debug logging

The log entries added will allow a user to track if the benchmark is
waiting for something or it has stuck.

_is_cluster_active method is not required anymore with a new wait
method.

Change-Id: I6994e382818262d728723ad0b9f780fa2f6d3c3e

wait_for helper improved to handle and log the status changes of the
resource. wait_for now accepts active_statuses, failure_statuses and attribute
name to perform status checks on the resource.

The wait_for method change is backward compatible so the current usages
are not affected.

The new methods added to handle specific wait cases:
* wait_is_ready - old wait_for symantics. Checks a resource with a
user-provided is_ready callable
* wait_for_status - implements waiting for specific resource status.
Logs the status changes.

Change-Id: I04f917033a02ca21fa1ad6eb55fcdb727ce82090
'}, {'number': 19, 'created': '2015-06-09 12:28:17.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/rally/commit/b8f0fcd0e923a88a23fc3d5e516fadcb20c55a17', 'message': 'Improved wait_for benchmark helper

wait_for helper improved to handle and log the status changes of the
resource. wait_for now accepts active_statuses, failure_statuses and attribute
name to perform status checks on the resource.

The wait_for method change is backward compatible so the current usages
are not affected.

The new methods added to handle specific wait cases:
* wait_is_ready - old wait_for symantics. Checks a resource with a
user-provided is_ready callable
* wait_for_status - implements waiting for specific resource status.
Logs the status changes.

commit_message:
Improved wait_for benchmark helper

wait_for helper improved to handle and log the status changes of the
resource. wait_for now accepts active_statuses, failure_statuses and attribute
name to perform status checks on the resource.

The wait_for method change is backward compatible so the current usages
are not affected.

The new methods added to handle specific wait cases:
* wait_is_ready - old wait_for symantics. Checks a resource with a
user-provided is_ready callable
* wait_for_status - implements waiting for specific resource status.
Logs the status changes.

Change-Id: I04f917033a02ca21fa1ad6eb55fcdb727ce82090
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/66/172466/16 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def get_status(resource, status_attr="status"): # Common case if ((hasattr(resource, status_attr) and isinstance(getattr(resource, status_attr), six.string_types))): return getattr(resource, status_attr).upper() # Dic case if ((isinstance(resource, dict) and status_attr in resource.keys() and isinstance(resource[status_attr], six.string_types))): return resource[status_attr].upper() return "NONE"def wait_for_status(resource, ready_statuses, failure_statuses=[], status_attr="status", update_resource=None, timeout=60, check_interval=1): """Waits for the given resource to come into the one of the given statuses. The provided resource should have status_att. It may be an object attribute or a dictionary key. The value of the attribute is checked against ready statuses list and failure statuses. In case of a failure the wait exits with an exception. The resource is updated between iterations with an update_resource call. :param ready_statuses: List of statuses which mean that the resource is ready :param failure_statuses: List of statuses which mean that an error has occurred while waiting for the resource :param status_attr: The name of the status attribute of the resource :param update_resource: Function that should take the resource object and return an 'updated' resource. If set to None, no result updating is performed :param timeout: Timeout in seconds after which a TimeoutException will be raised :param check_interval: Interval in seconds between the two consecutive readiness checks :returns: The "ready" resource object """ if not ready_statuses: raise exceptions.TaskInvalidStatus( "Cant wait for resource's %s status. No ready statuses provided" % resource) # make all statuses upper case ready_statuses = map(lambda x: x.upper(), ready_statuses) failure_statuses = map(lambda x: x.upper(), failure_statuses) start = time.time() latest_status = get_status(resource, status_attr) latest_status_update = start while True: if update_resource: resource = update_resource(resource) status = get_status(resource, status_attr) if status != latest_status: current_time = time.time() delta = current_time - latest_status_update LOG.debug("Waiting for resource %s. Status changed %s => %s in %s" % (resource, latest_status, status, delta)) latest_status = status latest_status_update = current_time if status in ready_statuses: break if status in failure_statuses: raise exceptions.TaskInvalidStatus( "Resource %s has come into %s status" % (resource, status)) time.sleep(check_interval) if time.time() - start > timeout: raise exceptions.TimeoutException( desired_status=ready_statuses, resource_name=getattr(resource, "name", repr(resource)), resource_type=resource.__class__.__name__, resource_id=getattr(resource, "id", "<no id>"), resource_status=get_status(resource)) return resource

commit_message:
Install data files in proper path

Bash completion script is installed in /usr/local/etc, so
install_rally.sh should make a symlink in /etc/bash_completion.d/

Also move `data_files` section from setup.py to setup.cfg

Closes-Bug: 1463038
Change-Id: Ifd5f69e41aa8121129d6314130385f48e1690843
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/49/182849/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: data_files = /etc/bash_completion.d = etc/rally.bash_completion

commit_message:
Allow refreshing network info_cache in get_nw_info_for_instance

There has been a long-standing race bug in the gate where adding a
floating IP to an instance fails with a 400 because instance.info_cache
is None.

This change allows a caller to tell get_nw_info_for_instance to get the
latest network information from the network API if instance.info_cache
is not set.

A dependent change to the os-floating-ips extension will use this to
force the refresh if the network info_cache is not set on the instance
rather than error out.

Partial-Bug: #1249065

Change-Id: I326ffaaab941e9fb897a03da3512e4cb481e4a3e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/90/171390/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova import contextdef get_nw_info_for_instance(instance, network_api=None, refresh_if_none=False): """Get the cached network information for the given instance. :param instance: The instance from which to get cached network information. :param network_api: The network API to get the latest information if instance.info_cache is None and refresh_if_none is True. :param refresh_if_none: If True and instance.info_cache is None, calls network_api.get_instance_nw_info to refresh the cache. :return: nova.network.model.NetworkInfo object """ if instance.info_cache is None: if network_api is not None and refresh_if_none: return network_api.get_instance_nw_info( context.get_admin_context(), instance)
deleted_lines: def get_nw_info_for_instance(instance): if instance.info_cache is None:

commit_message:
Reduce dataloss window through interrupted writes.

If we're interrupted mid-file-update we shouldn't leave the
requirements file half written. Instead write to a temp file and
rename into place.

Change-Id: I7c7c2553b90f756d74df1967369732b21b8e8c0d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/requirements refs/changes/06/190606/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Force a refresh of the network info_cache if not set in os-floating-ips

There has been a long-standing race bug in the gate where adding a
floating IP to an instance fails with a 400 because instance.info_cache
is None.

This forces a refresh of the network info_cache on the instance if it's
not set when attempting to add a floating IP to the instance.

Closes-Bug: #1249065

Change-Id: Idce55c0d1d17d70d403e57996ea8c9c143e54d6f

commit_message:
Revert patch-set "VMware: remove unused parameter for VMOPS spawn"

As part of networking-vsphere(OVSvApp solution) project, we have a
customised nova VCDriver which is overriding the spawn method and
using the power_on parameter to support OVSvApp Solution.

Hence, reverting this commit If719b94cf50d5f2212eac4807c80edb886bf7808
to enable the solution.

Reference:
https://github.com/stackforge/networking-vsphere
https://github.com/stackforge/networking-vsphere/blob/master/
networking_vsphere/nova/virt/vmwareapi/ovsvapp_vc_driver.py#L53

Change-Id: Ibd209e32fb83a5da6f931ccc358c28c3e01a11c5

commit_message:
Log the actual instance.info_cache when empty in floating ip associate

This attempts to add some enlightenment to the case where we try to
associate a floating ip for an instance and hit the case where there
is no info_cache. We need to know if it's actually None, or empty.

Related-Bug: #1249065

Change-Id: Ic0051d1d520f800d845b7006b5b95be5d8edf7c9

commit_message:
move setting of novncproxy_base_url

The fixes introduced in order to resolve
https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1409142 (CVE-2015-0259) make
novncproxy_base_url relevant on hosts running the nova-novncproxy
service, whereas previously it was only used by nova-compute to
construct VNC console urls.

This change moves the setting of the novncproxy_base_url option out of
compute.pp and into nova::vncproxy_common, where it can be used both
by compute.pp and vncproxy.pp.

Change-Id: I7af4cf8257f2bdbc7d3cc57930fd6371571db531
(cherry picked from commit 28268ad9c74370b193efe8e972c808d76bb8c8d7)

commit_message:
Add Host Mapping table to API Database

This patch creates the host_mappings table in the API database for cellsv2.
This table will contain mapping of compute hosts to cells.

Change-Id: I1bd35434ce186e1fb49d56c621bff3f09aa90138
Implements: blueprint cells-host-mapping

added_lines: def _check_003(self, engine, data): for column in ['created_at', 'updated_at', 'id', 'cell_id', 'host']: self.assertColumnExists(engine, 'host_mappings', column) self.assertIndexExists(engine, 'host_mappings', 'host_idx') self.assertUniqueConstraintExists(engine, 'host_mappings', ['host']) inspector = reflection.Inspector.from_engine(engine) # There should only be one foreign key here fk = inspector.get_foreign_keys('instance_mappings')[0] self.assertEqual('cell_mappings', fk['referred_table']) self.assertEqual(['id'], fk['referred_columns']) self.assertEqual(['cell_id'], fk['constrained_columns'])

commit_message:
Use pyngus>=1.3.1

Pyngus 1.3.1 has been released and it fixes the issues that blocked the
gate last time. This version of the library is required for the amqp
driver in oslo.messaging.

Change-Id: I4ba583e062674b27ad873ca2228274f383f2bb22

commit_message:
Use monotonic lib. to avoid finding monotonic time function

That library already does this same/equivalent search and
ensures that a monotonically increasing time is made available
so we can just avoid looking around for it ourselves.

Depends-On: Ia802cf5bc605aa428596731d86d995e75d4fdd59

Change-Id: I6b99a3eb90c766ff73726170f61697fbfacad7bb

deleted_lines: try: now = time.monotonic # noqa except AttributeError: try: # Try to use the pypi module if it's available (optionally...) from monotonic import monotonic as now # noqa except (AttributeError, ImportError): # Ok fallback to the non-monotonic one... now = time.time # noqa

commit_message:
Set default pass in aio scripts to be random

In the bootstrap-aio.sh and osad-aio-heat-template.yml we use a default
password of "secrete". As a minor security concern, this patch adjusts
this to be random.

Change-Id: I54b9a085aba7845b7a9ad435c60604359921fc09
Closes-Bug: #1462000
(cherry picked from commit 888f0ec87adec9ff7b633755e30015b2e813e95c)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/62/192162/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: DEFAULT_PASSWORD=$(head -c 64 /dev/urandom | tr -dc 'a-zA-Z0-9') export ADMIN_PASSWORD=${ADMIN_PASSWORD:-$DEFAULT_PASSWORD}

subject: Fix support for auth_uri setting in neutron provider
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-06-11 13:18:18.000000000', 'files': ['lib/puppet/provider/neutron.rb'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-neutron/commit/c030ab8444469858bbcb7484214fcd9592f1e688', 'message': "Fix support for auth_uri setting in neutron provider

Neutron provider still uses auth_port and auth_host config
options even though those are now deprecated and won't be set
if someone chooses to use auth_uri. This commit adds support
for auth_uri and keeps the provider backwards compatible.


Change-Id: I4824c09e6af4a800b5ac0c22bf5daea99452bd7e
(cherry picked from commit 6fb01efe21669a1a2408ca7aba0efc421cb51bd9)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix support for auth_uri setting in neutron provider

Neutron provider still uses auth_port and auth_host config
options even though those are now deprecated and won't be set
if someone chooses to use auth_uri. This commit adds support
for auth_uri and keeps the provider backwards compatible.


Change-Id: I4824c09e6af4a800b5ac0c22bf5daea99452bd7e
(cherry picked from commit 6fb01efe21669a1a2408ca7aba0efc421cb51bd9)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-neutron refs/changes/34/190634/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: auth_keys = ['admin_tenant_name', 'admin_user', 'admin_password'] deprecated_auth_url = ['auth_host', 'auth_port', 'auth_protocol'] auth_keys.all?{|k| !conf['keystone_authtoken'][k].nil?} and ( deprecated_auth_url.all?{|k| !conf['keystone_authtoken'][k].nil?} or !conf['keystone_authtoken']['auth_uri'].nil? ) if !conf['keystone_authtoken']['auth_uri'].nil? creds['auth_uri'] = conf['keystone_authtoken']['auth_uri'] else q = conf['keystone_authtoken'] creds['auth_uri'] = "#{q['auth_protocol']}://#{q['auth_host']}:#{q['auth_port']}/v2.0/" end if q['auth_uri'].nil? return "#{q['auth_protocol']}://#{q['auth_host']}:#{q['auth_port']}/v2.0/" else return "#{q['auth_uri']}".strip end

commit_message:
Add "enroll" state to the state machine

This spec describes introduction of ``enroll`` state, which we previously
agreed to introduce in the new state machine spec.

Spec for blueprint enroll-node-state

Change-Id: I2b39f265e864c58ec70a1a06efcc65e5d5d5b115
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/51/179151/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================== Add "enroll" state to the state machine ================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/enroll-node-state This blueprint describes introduction of ``enroll`` state, which we previously agreed to introduce in the `new state machine spec`_. Problem description =================== Currently nodes on creation get into ``available`` state, which is designed as a replacement for ``NOSTATE``. Such nodes will instantly be available to Nova for deployment, provided they have all the required properties. However, new state machine accounts for at least inspection and some ready state features like zapping, which should be done before node even gets into ``available`` state. Even worse, cleaning feature introduced in Kilo cycle should also happen before node becomes ``available``. Proposed change =============== * Add new state ``enroll``, from which node can be transition into ``manageable`` state by action called ``validate``. * ``validate`` transition will cause power and management interfaces to be validated on node. On success, node will get to ``manageable`` state. On failure, it will get back to ``enroll`` and ``last_error`` will be set. * Introduce new API microversion, making newly created nodes appear in ``enroll`` state instead of ``available``. * Release new major version of ``ironicclient`` defaulting to this new microversion. Alternatives ------------ We can ask people to manually move nodes to ``manageable`` state before inspection or zapping. We also won't validate power and management interfaces. Data model impact ----------------- None State Machine Impact -------------------- * ``enroll`` becomes a valid node state with transitions to: * ``validation`` via ``validate`` action * ``validating`` becomes a valid transient node state with transitions to: * ``manageable`` on ``done`` * ``enroll`` on ``fail``. REST API impact --------------- * Add new API microversion. When it is declared by client, node creation API should default to creating nodes in ``enroll`` state. RPC API impact -------------- None Driver API impact ----------------- None Nova driver impact ------------------ Make sure that Nova driver won't use nodes in ``enroll`` state Security impact --------------- None expected Other end user impact --------------------- With new microversion nodes will appear in ``enroll`` state. 2 more steps should be taken to make them available for deploy: ``validate`` and ``provide``. Cleaning will happen, if enabled. Scalability impact ------------------ None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- See `Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility`_. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Dmitry Tantsur, IRC: dtantsur, LP: divius Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- * Create new states and transitions * Make ironicclient aware of new transition * Introduce new microversion with node defaulting to ``enroll`` on creation * (Optionally or later) default ironicclient to the new microversion Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= * Tempest tests should be modified to test ``enroll`` state. Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== * Change is backwards compatible, while it's not the default in ironicclient. * Once new microversion is the default in ironicclient, it will break existing flows Documentation Impact ==================== * Working with new state and transition should be documented * Upgrade notes should be updated References ========== .. _new state machine spec: http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/ironic-specs/specs/kilo/new-ironic-state-machine.html

revisions:

Currently the disk consumption of eph disk is based on
'ephemeral_gb' in flavor and instance; however, it's not accurate
because the eph disk is created based on user's input.
If eph disk is not specified, the eph disk will be created according
to the 'ephemeral_gb', if it's specified, the 'ephemeral_gb' will be
used as maximum eph disk can be created.
The patch get the real eph disk consumption and use it when doing

Change-Id: Ib668537e5472a9352261100726728193928b3512
Closes-Bug: #1315988
"}]
commit_message:
Correct the disk usage report in resource tracker

Currently the disk consumption of eph disk is based on
'ephemeral_gb' in flavor and instance; however, it's not accurate
because the eph disk is created based on user's input.
If eph disk is not specified, the eph disk will be created according
to the 'ephemeral_gb', if it's specified, the 'ephemeral_gb' will be
used as maximum eph disk can be created.
The patch get the real eph disk consumption and use it when doing
update for system disk.

Change-Id: Ib668537e5472a9352261100726728193928b3512
Closes-Bug: #1315988

commit_message:
Update requirements for stevedore

cliff requires pbr>=0.11,<2.0 but stevedore<1.5.0 requires
pbr>=0.6,!=0.7,<1.0 . That can't work for pbr versions >= 1.0.
So require at least stevedore>=1.5.0 which also requires

commit_message:
Conditionally expose resources based on roles

Use actual user roles to filter out from `resource-type-list` those resources
that current user can not create due to RBAC restrictions.

Specifies blueprint conditional-resource-exposure

Change-Id: Ic13c51ef04e8d6d740a46d9554267ada9d9c78d2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat-specs refs/changes/28/185528/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ===================================================== Conditional exposure of resources based on user roles ===================================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/conditional-resource-exposure Expose resources as available based on actual user roles. Problem description =================== Currently we unconditionally register and present to the user all resource plugins that we have in-tree. As we will move in-tree some contrib/ resources that require special roles for instantiation (e.g. Keystone resources) all users will see them as available despite that the user might not actually be able to use them due to RBAC restrictions. This would be confusing to users and facilitate later stack failure at creation instead of failing early at validation. Proposed change =============== Add optional config settings for every client specifying the list of required "special" roles to instantiate some of the resources of this service. Use these values during validation to compare the roles with the roles from the context to check for resource availability for the specific user who has made the request. Default value (empty list) will mean show the resource as available to any user. Alternatives ------------ Keep the things as they are continuing to confuse users and fail later than earlier for templates with resources that current user can not create without having special roles. Long term alternative / improvement would be to wait until Keystone implements fine grained policy control and querying as part of API. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Pavlo Shchelokovskyy <pshchelo> Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: liberty-1 Work Items ---------- - add config options for client plugins describing the required special roles list - add an attribute to resources requiring special roles that marks them as such - add validation step comparing the options from config with roles from context - unit tests - functional tests - configure heat to show Keystone resources for admin only - check if Keystone resources are listed if called from non-admin users - check that template containing Keystone resources is failing validation Dependencies ============ - blueprint keystone-based-resource-availability is implemented - admin-requiring resources are moved in-tree from contrib/

commit_message:
Conditionally expose resources based on services

Use endpoint list to filter out those actually unavailable resources
from `resource-type-list` and make templates containing them
fail faster at validation.

Spesifies blueprint keystone-based-resource-availability

Change-Id: I48553873294b4aedfad2fc722bca503bea5ad4a6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat-specs refs/changes/23/185123/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================= Conditional exposure of resources ================================= Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/conditional-resource-exposure Register resources based on presence of the service. Problem description =================== Currently we unconditionally register and present to the user all resource plugins that we have in-tree, even though the actual service is not installed in that particular cloud (e.g. Neutron resources on Nova-network based cloud or Sahara resources as it is not that frequently installed). This is confusing to the user ((s)he sees resources that can not actually be used as available) and facilitates late failure of instantiated template instead of failing at validation. The situation is only going to worsen itself as we move the contrib/ resources back in-tree, and we will probably accept in-tree resources for may more projects under the "Big Tent" governance model. Also, we will move in-tree some contrib/ resources that require special roles for instantiation (e.g. Keystone resources) that still would be presented to the user despite that the user might not actually be able to use them. Proposed change =============== Conditional exposure on endpoint availablility ---------------------------------------------- Add an additional validation step in the resource class that checks if the required endpoint is present. Endpoints can be accessed from the request context that is already available in the resource class as ``stack.context``. This method should be called from ``Resource.__new__`` and raise a ``StackValidationError`` when appropriate. The ``list_resource_types`` method should tolerate the ``StackValidationError`` and do not output resources raising this as part of available resources list. Client plugins must implement a ``service_type`` property to be used during validation and also during client instantiation. Every resource type must implement the ``default_client_plugin`` class attribute to be used in the base ``Resource`` class to validate the endpoints presence in the context. Conditional exposure on roles of the user ----------------------------------------- Add optional config settings for every client specifying the list of required "special" roles to instantiate some of the resources of this service. Use these values during validation to compare the roles with the roles from the context to check for resource availability for the specific user who has made the request. Default value (empty list) will mean show the resource as available to any user. Alternatives ------------ Keep the things as they are continuing to confuse users and fail later than earlier for templates with resources for services unavailable in the current deployment. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Pavlo Shchelokovskyy <pshchelo> Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: liberty-1 Work Items ---------- Endpoint-based condition ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ - changes in the client plugins - add ``default_client_plugin`` to all resource plugins - changes in the base resource class - changes in the ``list_resource_types`` and ``show_resource_type`` service methods - unit tests - scenario integration tests (based on some "exotic" resource) - check if resource is listed as available - check if template with resource validates Roles-based condition ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ - add config options for client plugins describing the required special roles list - add an attribute to resources requiring special roles that marks them as such - add validation step comparing the options from config with roles from context - unit tests - functional tests - configure heat to show Keystone resources for admin only - check if Keystone resources are listed if called from non-admin users - check that template containing Keystone resources is failing validation Dependencies ============ Roles-based condition --------------------- Moving admin-requiring resources from contrib/ in-tree.

Monitoring Guide has duplicated target (Heka).
This target should be removed from one of the files.

commit_message:
Publicize oslo_policy.opts.register

Some projects (e.g., Glance) do not use global Enforcer instances and so
would need to register options at least once before the first Enforcer
instance is created. By providing a public register function (like other
oslo and openstack libraries do), we ensure that all uses of oslo.policy
can register options at the appropriate time.

Closes-bug: 1430508
Change-Id: Ib1bb95c7d339e707623ee8a103ea1fcea9c801d5

commit_message:
Fix available.html.example in transfer-table directory

Our real life use case of transfer-table (Launch Instance > Select Flavor)
does not use the warningText filter to display quota error messages.
See: https://github.com/openstack/horizon/blob/master/openstack_dashboard
/static/dashboard/launch-instance/flavor/select-flavor-table.html#L64

This otherwise unused filter is removed in:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/191200/

Change-Id: I09709aeb00f093495d2b17f9b9f12b731ed8e415
Closes-Bug: #1465378

commit_message:
Sent in the topic when taskmanager setup

The old setup won't sent the topic in, then we can not
change the taskmanager_queue as we want. So add it.

Change-Id: Ib457e49c5e58df711a8b963689db4c053ed9d201
Closes-bug: #1462734

commit_message:
Create new stackforge project for Cathead

Cathead is a TLS certificate monitoring service that can work in
conjunction with Anchor and other CAs to retrieve and update
certificates.

Change-Id: I3ff10ab1701a376a5d42e00ea853338777f8b5d7

commit_message:
Do not update the average when iteration failed

Total duration and iteration count are not updated on failed iterations
but new average was still calculated. When the failed iteration was the
first one, this resulted to zero division error.

Use latest average instead of calculating a new one in case of
failed iteration.

Change-Id: I3465a5e3de7b5838941d8ed044bb8865c69aa852
Closes-bug: #1464135
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/24/191524/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.avg = self.total_duration / self.iterations

commit_message:
ofagent: Fix port_dead

Remove relevant flows on port_dead, so that it correctly
stops forwarding packets to/from admin_state_up=False ports.

Revealed by tempest test_update_instance_port_admin_state test case.

While i'm here, update docstring of port_dead.

(cherry-picked from networking-ofagent 92c9f3339811f332c89fc6e739f13a1a8fe733d1)
Closes-Bug: #1421098
Change-Id: I70ac46f77ed3f9fcfdb051abb4a5f09b81fb61b8

commit_message:
Remove doc repositories from projects.txt

The documentation repositories maintained by the OpenStack
Documentation team are currently all in projects.txt. They
are not installed together OpenStack server projects.

While the syncing of requirements is nice, it's not essential that
Documentation repo are part of requirements. The Documentation
repos have additional unique dependencies that are not needed by
other projects.

Still, the Documentation team likes to ensure that their requirements
are not conflicting with global requirements to allow editors and
developers reuse environments.

As discussed with Documentation team, remove these repositories
now (see thread starting at
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-docs/2015-April/006362.html).

Change-Id: I807b061cf697dc79b26ffdfbe023c32600ddd346
(cherry picked from commit 8c9cd8c29bb146ca013efae0c726350889d1cc64)

commit_message:
Fix http 500 when no accept header passed to secret GET /payload

Update secrets controller to catch the situation where no Accept
http header value is passed (or a blank value is passed).

Default to application/octet-stream as the Accept: header is not
required.

Change-Id: Icb940df639fb98ee594e3a2b227ed3f753d28517
Closes-Bug: 1462681

""" test_model = secret_models.SecretModel( **self.default_secret_create_data) resp, secret_ref = self.behaviors.create_secret(test_model) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 201) get_resp = self.behaviors.get_secret( secret_ref, payload_content_type='') self.assertEqual(get_resp.status_code, 200) self.assertIn(test_model.payload, binascii.b2a_base64(get_resp.content))

You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import os import fixtures from oslo_config import cfg from oslo_policy import opts as policy_opts from magnum.common import policy as magnum_policy from magnum.tests import fake_policy CONF = cfg.CONF class PolicyFixture(fixtures.Fixture): def __init__(self, compat=None): self.compat = compat def setUp(self): super(PolicyFixture, self).setUp() self.policy_dir = self.useFixture(fixtures.TempDir()) self.policy_file_name = os.path.join(self.policy_dir.path, 'policy.json') with open(self.policy_file_name, 'w') as policy_file: policy_file.write(fake_policy.get_policy_data(self.compat)) policy_opts.set_defaults(CONF) CONF.set_override('policy_file', self.policy_file_name, 'oslo_policy') magnum_policy._ENFORCER = None self.addCleanup(magnum_policy.init().clear)

subject: enhancement for the common policy enforce
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-06-10 12:08:13.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/magnum/commit/e308538f3ba586a2c9f8292f15d3afa783384fb9', 'message': 'enhancement for the common policy enforce

Now the magnum.common.policy just support an "enforce" method to
wsgi policy check.

And this "enforce" method should be inline the body of wsgi method.
Such as:
from magnum.common import policy
class BaysController(rest.RestController):
    ....
    @wsme_pecan.wsexpose(None, types.uuid_or_name, status_code=204)
    def delete(self, bay_ident):
        ... doc string ...
        policy.enforce(pecan.request.context, "bay:create")
        .... common stuff ....

This inline style is ugly.

Now this patch is improving it.
This patch uses a decorator for policy check.
With this decorator we can do the policy check as follow:
from magnum.common import policy
class BaysController(rest.RestController):
    ....
    @policy.enforce_wsgi("bay", "delete")
    @wsme_pecan.wsexpose(None, types.uuid_or_name, status_code=204)
    def delete(self, bay_ident):
        ...

Here: This decorator MUST appear first (the outermost decorator) on an API
method for it to work correctly.

The decorator use functools.wraps to decorator the wsgi function.
A common decorator(without functools.wraps) replaces the original function
with an new one, that means it will lose the information about the original
function, it would be a serious problem for pcen wsgi.
That's why we have functools.wraps. This takes a function used in a decorator
and adds the functionality of copying over the function name, docstring,
arguments list, etc.

ref: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/308999/what-does-functools-wraps-do

Co-Authored-By: ShaoHe Feng <shaohe.feng@intel.com>
Change-Id: I9a7baf9559ff924ca4e261db2961b9d3c8763325
Partial-implements: blueprint policy-enfore

commit_message:
enhancement for the common policy enforce

Now the magnum.common.policy just support an "enforce" method to
wsgi policy check.

And this "enforce" method should be inline the body of wsgi method.
Such as:
from magnum.common import policy
class BaysController(rest.RestController):
    ....
    @wsme_pecan.wsexpose(None, types.uuid_or_name, status_code=204)
    def delete(self, bay_ident):
        ... doc string ...
        policy.enforce(pecan.request.context, "bay:create")
        .... common stuff ....

This inline style is ugly.

Now this patch is improving it.
This patch uses a decorator for policy check.
With this decorator we can do the policy check as follow:
from magnum.common import policy
class BaysController(rest.RestController):
    ....
    @policy.enforce_wsgi("bay", "delete")
    @wsme_pecan.wsexpose(None, types.uuid_or_name, status_code=204)
    def delete(self, bay_ident):
        ...

Here: This decorator MUST appear first (the outermost decorator) on an API
method for it to work correctly.

The decorator use functools.wraps to decorator the wsgi function.
A common decorator(without functools.wraps) replaces the original function
with an new one, that means it will lose the information about the original
function, it would be a serious problem for pcen wsgi.
That's why we have functools.wraps. This takes a function used in a decorator
and adds the functionality of copying over the function name, docstring,
arguments list, etc.

ref: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/308999/what-does-functools-wraps-do

Co-Authored-By: yuntongjin <yuntong.jin@intel.com>
Change-Id: I9a7baf9559ff924ca4e261db2961b9d3c8763325
Partial-implements: blueprint policy-enforce
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/magnum refs/changes/40/190140/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from functools import wrapsimport pecan # NOTE(Shaohe Feng): This decorator MUST appear first (the outermost # decorator) on an API method for it to work correctly def enforce_wsgi(api_name, act=None): """This is a decorator to simplify wsgi action policy rule check. :param api_name: The collection name to be evaluate. :param act: The function name of wsgi action. example: from magnum.common import policy class BaysController(rest.RestController): .... @policy.enforce_wsgi("bay", "delete") @wsme_pecan.wsexpose(None, types.uuid_or_name, status_code=204) def delete(self, bay_ident): ... """ def wraper(fn): action = "%s:%s" % (api_name, (act or fn.func_name)) @wraps(fn) def handle(self, *args, **kwargs): enforce(pecan.request.context, action, None) return fn(self, *args, **kwargs) return handle return wraper

commit_message:
Allow to run patching on pre-defined tests

- Add variable to settings.py to specify particular test
to run patching on
- Modify map_tests() function to set as patching dependent test
that was exported

Change-Id: I2fd5e74343f334d59f341aa3f0700134cd902de4
Implements: blueprint mos-patching-tests

commit_message:
Add a route table manager

This class manages the /etc/iproute2/rt_tables file to assign each
scope id a unique routing table.  It uses a namespace specific table
so that the table in the root namespace remains untouched.

Change-Id: Ibdbaff4717d04948a11afadb421e625de072888a
Partially-implements:  blueprint address-scopes
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/27/192027/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2014 Hewlett-Packard Development Company, L.P. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import mock import shutil import tempfile from neutron.agent.l3 import rt_tables from neutron.agent.linux import utils as linux_utils from neutron.tests import base def mock_netnamespace_directory(function): tmpdir = tempfile.mkdtemp() # Execute that never runs as root orig_execute = linux_utils.execute def execute_no_root(*args, **kwargs): kwargs['run_as_root'] = False orig_execute(*args, **kwargs) def inner(*args, **kwargs): try: cls = rt_tables.NamespaceEtcDir with mock.patch.object(linux_utils, 'execute') as execute,\ mock.patch.object(cls, 'BASE_DIR', tmpdir): execute.side_effect = execute_no_root function(*args, **kwargs) finally: shutil.rmtree(tmpdir) return inner class TestRoutingTablesManager(base.BaseTestCase): def setUp(self): super(TestRoutingTablesManager, self).setUp() self.ns_name = "fakens" self.scope_id = "fakescope" @mock_netnamespace_directory def test_default_tables(self): rtm = rt_tables.RoutingTablesManager(self.ns_name) self.assertEqual(253, rtm.get_table_id("default")) self.assertEqual(254, rtm.get_table_id("main")) self.assertEqual(255, rtm.get_table_id("local")) self.assertEqual(0, rtm.get_table_id("unspec")) @mock_netnamespace_directory def test_add_address_scope(self): rtm = rt_tables.RoutingTablesManager(self.ns_name) table_id = rtm.add_address_scope(self.scope_id) self.assertGreaterEqual(table_id, 1024) table_id_recorded = rtm.get_table_id(self.scope_id) self.assertEqual(table_id, table_id_recorded) @mock_netnamespace_directory def test_delete_address_scope(self): rtm = rt_tables.RoutingTablesManager(self.ns_name) rtm.add_address_scope(self.scope_id) rtm.delete_address_scope(self.scope_id) table_id_recorded = rtm.get_table_id(self.scope_id) self.assertIsNone(table_id_recorded)

commit_message:
DB downgrades are no longer supported

Commit 7aa4b75da9722496c4e166b44cc04973fd441f52 added a DB downgrade
test. This is no longer supported (since commit
e2e846f74b057f5f3ed72312b0b0ccf6ef97add2)

TrivialFix

added_lines: Sahara is the OpenStack Data processing service. Sahara performs two types of activities in OpenStack: * Hadoop cluster provisioning * Executing Elastic Data Processing (EDP) jobs Sahara runs as a single process service on each controller in MOS 6.x. This, however, will change in MOS 7.x. **Process checks** .. list-table:: :header-rows: 1 :widths: 20 20 20 20 20 :stub-columns: 0 :class: borderless * - Process name - Incoming connections - Role - Dependencies - HA mode * - sahara-all - HTTP 8386 - controller - db - active/active **API checks** Check the proper functioning of the API with a read operation. For example: * list provisioning plugins * GET /v1.1/<tenant-id>/plugins | | **Collected Metrics for Cluster related activities** .. list-table:: :header-rows: 1 :widths: 20 20 20 :stub-columns: 0 :class: borderless * - Metrics - Source - Purpose * - Total number of Sahara clusters in ``Active`` state - poll SQL: select count(*) from clusters where status="Active"; - diag * - Total number of Sahara clusters in ``Error`` state - poll SQL: select count(*) from clusters where status="Error"; - Alert: Too many clusters in ``Error`` state may be a sign of the provisioning engine failure or failures in other OpenStack services. * - Total number of Sahara clusters doing provisioning at the moment - poll SQL: select count(*) from clusters where status not in ("Active", "Error"); - Alert: Too many clusters in provisioning state may be a sign of a slow network throughput or even missing network connectivity between VMs. It may also be a sign of a corrupted image being used for the clusters. * - Total number of VMs used in Sahara clusters - poll SQL select count(*) from instances; - diag * - Total number of Cinder Volumes attached to Sahara VMs - poll SQL (cross project) select count(*) from cinder.volumes where instance_uuid in (select instance_id from sahara.instances) and attach_status="attached"; - diag * - Total number of Security Group Rules generated by Sahara - poll SQL (neutron) select count(*) from neutron.securitygrouprules where security_group_id in (select id from neutron.securitygroups where description LIKE "%Auto security group created by Sahara%"); - diag * - Total number of Floating IPs attached to Sahara VMs - poll SQL: select count(*) from instances where management_ip is not NULL; - diag * - Total number of Glance Images uploaded for Sahara clusters - poll SQL (glance): select count(*) from glance.image_properties where name="_sahara_username" and deleted=0; - diag **Collected Metrics for Elastic Data Processing (EDP) related activities** .. list-table:: :header-rows: 1 :widths: 20 20 20 :stub-columns: 0 :class: borderless * - Metrics - Source - Purpose * - Total number of EDP jobs that have finished successfully - poll SQL: select count(*) from job_executions where info like '%"status": "SUCCEEDED"%'; - diag * - Total number of EDP jobs that have failed - poll SQL: select count(*) from sahara.job_executions where info like '%"status": "KILLED"%' or info like '%"status": "Error"%'; - Alert: Too many errors in EDP may be a sign of deeper problems. * - Total number of EDP jobs that are running at the moment - poll SQL: select count(*) from sahara.job_executions where not info like '%"status": "KILLED"%' and not info like '%"status": "Error"%' and not info like '%"status": "SUCCEEDED"%'; - diag

commit_message:
Support recommendations in CDH plugin

We should support autoconfigurable hadoop configs in CDH plugin.
This patch does this job.

Implements bluprint: recommend-configuration

Change-Id: I3d938236786aae8f5e923a3fc3ef35ba24630e74
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara refs/changes/71/185371/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2015 Mirantis Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or # implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. from sahara import conductor as cond from sahara import context from sahara.plugins import recommendations_utils as ru from sahara.plugins.vanilla.hadoop2 import config_helper as ch conductor = cond.API def _dfs_replication_recommendations(pctx, cluster): configs = ['dfs_replication'] if not ru.can_be_recommended(cluster.cluster_configs, 'HDFS', configs): return {} current_configs = cluster.cluster_configs.to_dict().get('HDFS', {}) datanode_count = 0 for ng in cluster.node_groups: if 'DATANODE' in ng.node_processes: datanode_count += ng.count if datanode_count > 0: result = { 'dfs_replication': min( ch.get_config_value(pctx, 'HDFS', 'dfs_replication'), datanode_count) } result.update(current_configs) return {'HDFS': result} return {} def _recommended_mapreduce_configs(node_group, cluster_configs): configs = [ 'yarn_app_mapreduce_am_resource_mb', 'yarn_app_mapreduce_am_command_opts', 'mapreduce_map_memory_mb', 'mapreduce_reduce_memory_mb', 'mapreduce_map_java_opts', 'mapreduce_reduce_java_opts', 'mapreduce_task_io_sort_mb' ] if not ru.can_be_recommended(cluster_configs, "MapReduce", configs, node_group=node_group): return {} current_configs = node_group.node_configs.to_dict().get('MapReduce', {}) data = ru.get_node_group_data(node_group) ret = {} ret['yarn_app_mapreduce_am_resource_mb'] = data['amMemory'] ret['yarn_app_mapreduce_am_command_opts'] = ru.get_opts( 0.8 * data['amMemory']) ret['mapreduce_map_memory_mb'] = data['mapMemory'] ret['mapreduce_reduce_memory_mb'] = data['reduceMemory'] ret['mapreduce_map_java_opts'] = ru.get_opts(0.8 * data['mapMemory']) ret['mapreduce_reduce_java_opts'] = ru.get_opts( 0.8 * data['reduceMemory']) ret['mapreduce_task_io_sort_mb'] = int(min( 0.4 * data['mapMemory'], 1024)) ret.update(current_configs) return {'MapReduce': ret} def _recommended_yarn_configs(node_group, cluster_configs): configs = [ 'yarn_nodemanager_resource_memory_mb', 'yarn_scheduler_minimum_allocation_mb', 'yarn_scheduler_maximum_allocation_mb' ] if not ru.can_be_recommended(cluster_configs, "YARN", configs, node_group=node_group): return {} current_configs = node_group.node_configs.to_dict().get('YARN', {}) data = ru.get_node_group_data(node_group) r = {} r['yarn_nodemanager_resource_memory_mb'] = (data['containers'] * data['ramPerContainer']) r['yarn_scheduler_minimum_allocation_mb'] = data['ramPerContainer'] r['yarn_scheduler_maximum_allocation_mb'] = (data['containers'] * data['ramPerContainer']) r.update(current_configs) return {'YARN': r} def _modify_cluster_configs(pctx, cluster): cl_configs = cluster.cluster_configs.to_dict() ctx = context.ctx() cl_configs.update(_dfs_replication_recommendations(pctx, cluster)) conductor.cluster_update(ctx, cluster, {'cluster_configs': cl_configs}) def _modify_node_groups_configs(node_group, cluster): result = node_group.node_configs.to_dict() result.update(_recommended_yarn_configs(node_group, cluster.cluster_configs)) result.update(_recommended_mapreduce_configs(node_group, cluster.cluster_configs)) conductor.node_group_update(context.ctx(), node_group, {'node_configs': result}) def make_recommendations(pctx, cluster): _modify_cluster_configs(pctx, cluster) for node_group in cluster.node_groups: _modify_node_groups_configs(node_group, cluster)

[Spark] Add recommendation about dfs.replication

This patch adds simple recommendation about dfs.replication for
Spark plugin

Partially-Implements blueprint: recommend-configuration

Change-Id: Ic765ae7e6becf5c228825c299f2c525fbdd90c8c

added_lines: def recommend_configs(self, cluster): if not cluster.use_autoconfig: return configs = cluster.cluster_configs.to_dict() if 'HDFS' in configs and 'dfs.replication' in configs['HDFS']: return dn_count = utils.get_instances_count(cluster, 'datanode') hdfs_configs = configs.get('HDFS', {}) hdfs_configs.update({'dfs.replication': int(min( c_helper.get_config_value('HDFS', 'dfs.replication'), dn_count))}) configs.update({'HDFS': hdfs_configs}) conductor.cluster_update(context.ctx(), cluster, {'cluster_configs': configs})

subject: Introduced "naming conventions" SA feature
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-02-05 16:32:45.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/murano/commit/a1002d1c7fcac5306ec10e7454aafa23dfbabf26', 'message': 'Introduced "naming conventions" SA feature

In the current state some constraints has no defined names in the
project.

So they are generated by DB engine automatically and each DB generates
constraint names in its own fashion. This makes difficult to operate
with constraints, for example in migrations, where they should be
referred by names.

SQLAlchemy provides the feature for generation of constraint names
using patterns [1].

Leveraging it will bring consistency to constraints naming
in the project.

***IMPORTANT***

This revision also drops old migrations and starts migration from
scratch. It causes backward-incompatibility with previous versions.

Also SQLite support is dropped, migrations are no longer compatible with
this engine. It is no logner recommended to use it even for development.
However those who still wants to use SQLite can use introduced commands
"register_models" and "unregister_models". The first one generates
"CREATE TABLE" statements and syncs DB with models in one pass. The
second one does opposite.

[1] http://alembic.readthedocs.org/en/latest/naming.html#tutorial-constraint-names

Change-Id: Ie55843347c8bf0cbec162b1cfd2bad4d5fac1234
Related-Bug: #1399151
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-02-06 11:35:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/murano/commit/11445e2af35525d3d71e4c182994ba1c872e182d', 'message': 'Introduced "naming conventions" SA feature

In the current state some constraints has no defined names in the
project.

So they are generated by DB engine automatically and each DB generates
constraint names in its own fashion. This makes difficult to operate
with constraints, for example in migrations, where they should be
referred by names.

SQLAlchemy provides the feature for generation of constraint names
using patterns [1].

Leveraging it will bring consistency to constraints naming
in the project.

***IMPORTANT***

This revision also drops old migrations and starts migration from
scratch. It causes backward-incompatibility with previous versions.

Also SQLite support is dropped, migrations are no longer compatible with
this engine. It is no logner recommended to use it even for development.
However those who still wants to use SQLite can use introduced commands
"register_models" and "unregister_models". The first one generates
"CREATE TABLE" statements and syncs DB with models in one pass. The
second one does opposite.

[1] http://alembic.readthedocs.org/en/latest/naming.html#tutorial-constraint-names

Change-Id: Ie55843347c8bf0cbec162b1cfd2bad4d5fac1234
Related-Bug: #1399151
Closes-Bug: #1415436

commit_message:
Introduced "naming conventions" SA feature

In the current state some constraints has no defined names in the
project.

So they are generated by DB engine automatically and each DB generates
constraint names in its own fashion. This makes difficult to operate
with constraints, for example in migrations, where they should be
referred by names.

SQLAlchemy provides the feature for generation of constraint names
using patterns [1].

Leveraging it will bring consistency to constraints naming
in the project.

***IMPORTANT***

This revision also drops old migrations and starts migration from
scratch. It causes backward-incompatibility with previous versions.

Also SQLite support is dropped, migrations are no longer compatible with
this engine. It is no longer recommended to use it even for development.
However those who still wants to use SQLite can use introduced commands
"register_models" and "unregister_models". The first one generates
"CREATE TABLE" statements and syncs DB with models in one pass. The
second one does opposite.

[1] http://alembic.readthedocs.org/en/latest/naming.html#tutorial-constraint-names

Change-Id: Ie55843347c8bf0cbec162b1cfd2bad4d5fac1234
Related-Bug: #1399151

added_lines: Swift is the OpenStack project, which provides highly available, distributed and eventually consistent storage services for objects. It is used as a storage backend to store Glance images. Process Checks ++++++++++++++ .. list-table:: :header-rows: 1 :widths: 25 25 25 25 :stub-columns: 0 :class: borderless * - Process name - Incoming connection - Role - HA mode * - swift-proxy-server - HTTP 8080 - controller - active/active * - swift-object-replicator - RPC - controller - active/active * - swift-object-server - RPC - controller - active/active * - swift-container-server - HTTP 6001 - controller - active/active * - swift-container-replicator - RPC - controller - active/active * - swift-account-server - HTTP 6002 - controller - active/active * - swift-account-replicator - RPC - controller - active/active API Checks ++++++++++ Check the availability of the service through synthetic HTTP transactions against the Swift API endpoint: * create a container * upload a small object * delete the container and object Collected Metrics +++++++++++++++++ The Swift project is made to collect metrics natively. Indeed, it is the only OpenStack project that is natively instrumented to send metrics to `statsd`_ or any statsd enabled data acquisition service like `Heka`_. It provides real-time operational data about the object storage cluster activity and errors across all components. Please check the documentation for further information about how to enable statsd metrics in the `Swift developer documentation`_. .. _`statsd`: https://github.com/etsy/statsd/ .. _`Heka`: https://github.com/mozilla-services/heka .. _`Swift developer documentation`: http://docs.openstack.org/developer/swift/admin_guide.html#reporting-metrics-to-statsd

commit_message:
Fix Create User form's fields sorting for Django 1.7

Starting from Django 1.7 self.fields.keyOrder no longer works for
setting fields ordering, need to rearrange fields there by recreating
underlying OrderedDict.

Change-Id: If0f4c7014a7a68f2ff0d0f2cb06f7b1c2e28436b
Closes-Bug: #1465221
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/84/191784/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import collectionsimport django ordering = ["domain_id", "domain_name", "name", "email", "password", "confirm_password", "project", "role_id"] # Starting from 1.7 Django uses OrderedDict for fields and keyOrder # no longer works for it if django.VERSION >= (1, 7): self.fields = collections.OrderedDict( (key, self.base_fields[key]) for key in ordering) else: self.fields.keyOrder = ordering

commit_message:
Notification serialization of context

Notifications with oslo_messaging was throwing an error that the
TroveContext was not serialized properly.

Change-Id: I651db0b72dbf4cb860b2df37ac36ddadc9e328d2
Closes-Bug: #1430586

commit_message:
Drop OVS & LB monolitic plugins

OVS & LB monolitic plugins have been dropped from Neutron in Juno and
have been replaced in Havana by ML2 (in neutron::plugins::ml2::X and
neutron::agents::ml2::X).
It's time to clean this module by dropping useless plugins.

Change-Id: I62ecd46fbc74f3e30b66052a7f95ee7c96c3138f

commit_message:
Move swift_allow_all_users to role defaults

We currently default swift_allow_all_users in
etc/openstack_deploy/user_variables.yml instead of
playbooks/roles/os_swift/defaults/main.yml.  If a deployer removes this
variable from etc/openstack_deploy/user_variables.yml, the swift
playbook will fail.  This commit moves the variable default to
playbooks/roles/os_swift/defaults/main.yml.

Change-Id: I9a73eda990327bf427f40a13965484fde00cbe21
Closes-Bug: #1424981
(cherry picked from commit 495f8b31d6400b50d0c64bba7ede7cbc4b181d23)

commit_message:
Enable python34 tests for nova/tests/unit/virt/vmwareapi/test*.py

Two tests still need work, they are commented out in tox.ini
py34 target as a reminder. All other tests in
nova/tests/unit/virt/vmwareapi/test*.py were added to the py34
tox target

Change-Id: I4739822765af2af65f012e53c278933720cf2650

commit_message:
Block deploy/provision action for unassigned nodes

If user will try to provision or deploy node that is not
assigned to any environment, error will be printed.
Also removed required "env" param for deploy/provision
action since it's not used there.

Change-Id: I3787c50cb5284b43cbb44261da000baf040cc684
Closes-Bug: #1445531
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-fuelclient refs/changes/80/178580/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # -*- coding: utf-8 -*- # Copyright 2015 Mirantis, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import mock from six import StringIO from fuelclient.cli.actions import node from fuelclient.tests import base GRAPH_API_OUTPUT = "digraph G { A -> B -> C }" TASKS_API_OUTPUT = [ {'id': 'primary-controller'}, {'id': 'sync-time'}, ] class TestNodeStartAction(base.UnitTestCase): @mock.patch.object(node.NodeAction, 'get_env_id', return_value=None) def test_node_not_assigend(self, _): for method in ('--deploy', '--provision'): with mock.patch('sys.stderr', new=StringIO()) as mstderr: with self.assertRaises(SystemExit): self.execute(['fuel', 'node', method, '--node', '8']) self.assertIn( "Input nodes are not assigned to any environment!", mstderr.getvalue())

subject: Amend resource objects proposal

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-06-05 12:32:03.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs/commit/d2b4e69f6dd6e70357cb7569a5db8ca94a40d3fb', 'message': 'Amend resource objects proposal

Jay drew a hard line between amounts and usages, whereas I think those
are the same. I draw the hard line between amounts and requests.

I also want to be able to deal with resources which are not easily
dealt with as independent integer resources.

Work in progress!

commit_message:
Amend resource objects proposal

We agreed that Usage wasn't the most useful term. Rewrite in terms of
Inventories.

Get rid of the conductor RPC method - we'll just use ComputeNode#save.

Fix some minor nits.

Change-Id: Idceba6dd53e4c4827e37f9e01b34a89455783d39
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/59/188759/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: resources that are consumed on the node. The ``ResourceTracker.old_resources`` attribute is a dictionary containing a clutter of nested dictionaries. Some ofan object in ``nova.virt.hardware``, and a 'metrics' dictionary with completelyunstructured nested dictionaries, the ``ResourceTracker.old_resources``- ``local_gb_used``: Amount of disk in GB used on the compute node - ``local_gb``: Total GB of local disk capacity the compute node provides - ``free_disk_gb``: Calculated amount of disk the compute node has available - ``vcpus_used``: Number of vCPUs consumed on the compute node - ``vcpus``: Total number of vCPUs the compute node provides - ``free_vcpus``: Calculated number of vCPUs the compute node has available - ``memory_mb_used``: Amount of RAM in MB used on the compute node - ``memory_mb``: Total MB of RAM capacity the compute node provides - ``free_ram_mb``: Calculated amount of RAM the compute node has available - ``running_vms``: Number of virtual machine instances running on the node - ``current_workload``: Some calculated value of the workload on the node``scheduler_client.update_resource_stats()`` method, passing in this resources[resource_type].consume(amount, sign)priority for the Liberty release.Model ----- scheduler or resource tracker interfaces. This spec proposes the addition of the following abstract ``nova.objects`` classes: - ``AmountType``: subclasses hold concrete quantities of the type they represent, EG "CPUs 0-4 + 2GB RAM in NUMA node 0 and the same in NUMA node 1". - Implemented by: ``IntegerAmountType``, ``NUMAAmountType``, ``PCIAmountType``... - ``NUMAAmountType`` (for example) offers: - ``provide(NUMATopology)``. Adds the given ``NUMATopology`` to the set of free NUMA resources. - ``consume(NUMATopology)``. Subtracts the given ``NUMATopology`` from the set of free NUMA resources. - ``ResourceAmount``: subclasses describe concrete resources from a particular ``AmountSet`` (see below). Has an ``AmountType`` and both proxies and adapts its methods. EG ``IntegerAmountType#provide(Integer)`` can be called as ``VCPUAmount#provide(Integer)`` or ``VCPUAmount#provide(VCPUAmount)``, but not ``VCPUAmount(RAMAmount)`` even though ``RAMAmount`` also has an ``IntegerAmountType``. - As part of a ``AmountSet``: "xyz.test.com provides 4096 of RAM". - As part of a ``ResourceClaim``: "I hold 2048 of RAM on xyz.test.com". - Implemented by: ``RAMAmount``, ``NUMAAmount``, ``PCIAmount``... - ``RequestType``: subclasses describe abstract requests for resources of a type, EG "2 CPUs + 1GB RAM in a single NUMA node". - Implemented by: ``IntegerRequestType``, ``NUMARequestType``, ``PCIRequestType``... - ``NUMARequestType`` (for example) offers: - ``match(NUMAAmount)``. Finds specific resources in the ``NUMAAmount`` which match this request and returns them as a ``NUMATopology``. - ``ResourceRequest``: subclasses describe abstract requests for particular resources, EG "I need 2048 of RAM". Has a ``RequestType`` and both proxies and adapts its methods. EG ``IntegerRequestType#match(Integer)`` can be called as ``VCPURequest#match(Integer)`` or ``VCPURequest#match(VCPURequest)``, but not ``VCPURequest(RAMRequest)`` even though ``RAMRequest`` also has an ``IntegerRequestType``. - Implemented by: ``VCPUResourceUsage``, ``RAMResourceUsage``, ``DiskResourceUsage``... Plus the following container types, also as ``nova.objects`` classes: - ``AmountSet``, which is a set of ``ResourceAmounts``. - ``RequestSet``, which is a set of ``ResourceRequests``. When fulfilling the request, all of these must be matched against a single ``AmountSet``. Requests which span multiple ``AmountSets`` should be submitted in a single API call as a set of ``AmountSets``. - ``ResourceClaim``, which is a ``AmountSet`` representing a fulfilled ``RequestSet``. These relationships may be illustrated as:: +----------------+ +-----------------+ | AmountType | | RequestType | +----------------+ +-----------------+ | | v M v M +----------------+ +-----------------+ | ResourceAmount | | ResourceRequest | +----------------+ +-----------------+ ^ M ^ M | | +----------------+ +-----------------+ | AmountSet | | RequestSet | +----------------+ +-----------------+ | | | | v M v M +-------------------+ | ResourceClaim | +-------------------+ This spec removes the extensible resource tracker (ERT) because it does not offer the stability of object versioning. However, the goals the ERT served of allowing for new resource types and resource accounting methods are acknowledged and are expected to be served by the proposed implementation. This spec discusses resources, whose allocation changes when a scheduling decision is made. It does not cover metrics, which change according to the state of the host. Examples include temperature, network throughput and power consumption. Nor does it cover properties, which are set centrally and only changed by administrative action. This spec does NOT propose any changes to the database schema of the ``compute_node`` table or the fields in ``ComputeNode``.None. The objects added in this blueprint will not be stored in a database.The ERT will be removed when this blueprint is completed.request_spec will be more structured, and much of the spaghetti code in the resource tracker around the ERT, PCI tracker and NUMA topology quirks will go away. .. *********************************************************** *********************************************************** **** **** **** WORK IN PROGRESS!!! WORK IN PROGRESS!!! **** **** **** *********************************************************** *********************************************************** .. This section has not been worked on yet! The resource tracker code will be converted to use these classes when representing usage of all resources on a compute node. The data returned from the hypervisor will be immediately converted to a ``AmountSet`` and the instance, migrations and orphaned instances will be received as ``ResourceClaims``. Since these are necessarily all against the same ``AmountSet``, these may be summed by resource and reported in aggregate. , however we do add translation methods to ``ComputeNode`` that will be able to construct a set of ``ResourceClaim`` objects for each allocation on the compute node as well as set the existing fields on the ``ComputeNode`` object from supplied ``AmountSet`` and ``ResourceClaim`` object. A set of interfaces will be provided: class ResourceType(object): def matches(self, request, pool_resource) class ResourceClaim(object): """Represents a claim on a specific set of resources.""" def add(self, claim): """Returns a claim representing the union of this claim and the one passed in.""" def remove(self, claim): """Returns a claim excluding any resources in the claim passed in.""" raise NotImplementedError class AmountSet(object): :param amount_spec: ``AmountSpec`` to determine if there is room for. If the supplied ``amount_spec`` is negative, returns False .The conductor RPC API should have a new ``update_compute_node_resource_usages()`` method added to it that passes the new ``nova.objects.ResourceUsageCollection`` object to the conductor, that the conductor decomposes and updates the compute node records in the database.- Add translation methods to ``nova.objects.ComputeNode`` to construct and decompose a set of ``UsageSpec`` objects w/ unit tests 'numa_topology' key and ``nova.virt.hardware.VirtNUMATopology`` object in the ``old_resources`` dictionary. and 'pci_passthrough_devices' keys and a ``nova.pci.pci_stats.PciDeviceStats`` object in the ``pci_tracker`` attribute of the resource tracker. - Convert the virt driver's ``get_available_resources`` method to return a ``update_compute_node_resource_usages()`` that supplies the new ``nova.objects.ResourceUsageCollection`` object representation of resource- Deprecate the old ``update_resource_stats()`` conductor RPC API method. - Convert the scheduler's ``HostStateManager`` to utilize the new ``ComputeNode.get_resource_usages()`` method and ``ComputeNode.update_from_resource_usages`` method.- `add-useful-metrics`
deleted_lines: resources that are consumed on the node. The `ResourceTracker.old_resources` attribute is a dictionary with a bunch of random nested dictionaries. Some ofan object in `nova.virt.hardware`, and a 'metrics' dictionary with completelyunstructured nested dictionaries, the `ResourceTracker.old_resources`- `local_gb_used`: Amount of disk in GB used on the compute node - `local_gb`: Total GB of local disk capacity the compute node provides - `free_disk_gb`: Calculated amount of disk the compute node has available - `vcpus_used`: Number of vCPUs consumed on the compute node - `vcpus`: Total number of vCPUs the compute node provides - `free_vcpus`: Calculated number of vCPUs the compute node has available - `memory_mb_used`: Amount of RAM in MB used on the compute node - `memory_mb`: Total MB of RAM capacity the compute node provides - `free_ram_mb`: Calculated amount of RAM the compute node has available - `running_vms`: Number of virtual machine instances running on the node - `current_workload`: Some calculated value of the workload on the node`scheduler_client.update_resource_stats()` method, passing in this resources[resource_type].consume(amount*sign)priority for the Kilo release.scheduler or resource tracker interfaces. This blueprint encompasses the addition of a set of model objects: - A set of classes that represent amounts of different types of resources - A set of classes that represent usage of different types of resources - A set of classes that represent different types of resources These amount, usage, and resource type classes will be `nova.objects` object classes, and will enable Nova evolve, in a versioned manner, the way that it tracks resources and exposes usage data about consumed resources. The goals of the extensible resource tracker was to put in place a framework that allowed adding new resource types and allowed accounting for those resources in different ways. While this blueprint does indeed remove the extensible resource tracker, because these amount, usage, and resource type classes are being added as `nova.object` objects, we will gain the ability to evolve and enhance our resource tracking with object versioning and adding new resource type classes. This approach will provide the flexibility that the ERT intended, but with the stability that the nova objects system. The resource tracker code will then be converted to use the above classes when representing usage of all resources on a compute node. A new conductor RPC API method `update_compute_node_resource_usages` method will be added that gets a `nova.objects.ComputeNode` object and a `nova.objects.ResourceUsageCollection` object and updates the compute node database record with the resource usage amounts/data coming from the resource tracker. Note that we do NOT propose any changes at this time to the database schema of the `compute_nodes` table or the fields in `nova.objects.ComputeNode`, however we do add translation methods to `nova.objects.ComputeNode` that will be able to construct a set of `UsageSpec` objects for each resource type on the compute node as well as set the existing fields on the `nova.objects.ComputeNode` object from a supplied set of `UsageSpec` objects.None. The objects added in this blueprint are not stored in a database. These objects are a replacement for an unstructured nested dictionary that is currently used to represent resource amounts.The extensible resource tracker will be removed when this blueprint is completed.request_spec will be much more structured, and much of the spaghetti code in the resource tracker around the ERT, PCI tracker, and NUMA topology quirks will go away.There will be a generalized usage spec class interface that looks like this: class UsageSpec(object): """Represents the used amount of a particular type of resource.""" def update(self, amount_spec): """Update the used amount of resources by the supplied amount. :param amount_spec: `AmountSpec` to modify the usage with. """ :param amount_spec: `AmountSpec` to determine if there is room for. If the supplied `amount_spec` is negative, returns False .The conductor RPC API should have a new `update_compute_node_resource_usages()` method added to it that passes the new `nova.objects.ResourceUsageCollection` object to the conductor, that the conductor decomposes and updates the compute node records in the database.- Add translation methods to `nova.objects.ComputeNode` to construct and decompose a set of `UsageSpec` objects w/ unit tests 'numa_topology' key and `nova.virt.hardware.VirtNUMATopology` object in the `old_resources` dictionary. and 'pci_passthrough_devices' keys and a `nova.pci.pci_stats.PciDeviceStats` object in the `pci_tracker` attribute of the resource tracker. - Convert the virt driver's `get_available_resources` method to return a `update_compute_node_resource_usages()` that supplies the new `nova.objects.ResourceUsageCollection` object representation of resource- Deprecate the old update_resource_stats() conductor RPC API method. - Convert the scheduler's `HostStateManager` to utilize the new `ComputeNode.get_resource_usages()` method and `ComputeNode.update_from_resource_usages` method.

commit_message:
Update usage documentation

This updates the usage document to clarify the helper functions
used to create cloud connections, and also adds documentation to
those functions.

Change-Id: I4dd76b312db21e65c464ac6634a4bd005b0f49d0

added_lines: """ Create connections to multiple OpenStack clouds. This will instantiate one :class:`OpenStackCloud` object for each cloud definition found within the cloud configuration file. :returns: A list of :class:`OpenStackCloud` objects. """ """ Create a connection to a single OpenStack cloud. Instantiates an :class:`OpenStackCloud` object using the cloud named in the `config` parameter and found in the cloud configuration file, or from the OpenStack environment variables (OS_*) if they exist and a name is not supplied. :returns: A single :class:`OpenStackCloud` object. """ """ Create a operator-level connection to a single OpenStack cloud. Creates an :class:`OperatorCloud` object using the cloud named in the `config` parameter and found in the cloud configuration file, or from the OpenStack environment variables (OS_*) if they exist and a name is not supplied. :returns: A single :class:`OperatorCloud` object. """

added_lines: The *neutron-dhcp-agent* relies on **dnsmasq** to handle the DHCP requests which provide network configuration to instances. | We recommend you perform the following checks to detect anomalies: * There must be at least one **dnsmasq** process per tenant network when DHCP is enabled. * Too many DHCPNAK entries in dnsmasq logs could be the symptom of connectivity issues with the instances.

commit_message:
Replace dict(obj.iteritems() with dict(obj)

Since oslo.db 1.10, it's possible to convert directly a SQLAlchemy
object to a dictionary using dict(obj) instead of having to write
dict(obj.iteritems()).

dict(obj) works also on regular dictionaries to duplicate a dictionary.

Blueprint cinder-python3
Change-Id: I868a055d5bbfe6646aad3e36e1bf6c7a1ad7b449
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/64/191064/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
